text: Human Story 3 is a studio album by American electronic musician James Ferraro, self-released on June 14, 2016. The album's concept revolves philosophically and structurally on how technology that can be used meaningfully is often used less usefully for commerce and, as a result, how the technology may eventually end up subverting humanness. The record landed at number seven on Tiny Mix Tapes' year-end list of the best albums of 2016. ==Composition and concept== Human Story 3 conceptually and, by its ambiguous narrative, revolves around a "smart planet" where service robots, performed by text-to-speech voices, attempt to cognitively interpret the world around them but are at the same time musically shown as still performing repetitive tasks. The aim and moral of the record is that while technology can do a lot of commands that are beneficial, it ends up only being used less usefully for commerce and, as a result, the technology may eventually end up subverting humanness.Gaca, Anna (August 18, 2016). "A Conversation With James Ferraro, Critical Futurist". Spin. SpinMedia. Retrieved January 22, 2017. The word salads in the titles of cuts such as "Immanent Cloud," "Security Broker," or "Plastic Ocean" cause the meaning of symbols to be changed, much like how marketers alter the meaning of some objects to create what Ferraro described as strange and "contradictory" products.Grunenberg, Robert. "James Ferraro and Mall Aesthetics". SSense. Retrieved January 23, 2017. The text-to-speech voices often display slight mispronunciations, which give the album a surrealistic feel regarding how technology sometimes fails to replicate human cognition. As Ferraro said, "Certain newer apps tend to bring people together – in a mechanical, artificial way – in shared space. I think that’s probably the trend, post- this hyper-individual era. So it’s obviously going to be unnatural if it’s being manipulated through a third party like that—a bit alien." Human Story 3 follows several text-to-speech characters, male and female voices, that repeat brand names, buzzwords and phrases like "IKEA," "GPS," "Starbucks," "market crash," "mobile payments," "FedEx," "smart car" and "latte" at musical swells and crescendos, along with detailed speeches. Mehan Jayasuriya of Pitchfork wrote that this dialogue feels "like a torrent of audio pop-ups that can’t be blocked."Jayasuriya, Mehan (July 1, 2016). "James Ferraro: Human Story 3". Pitchfork. Conde Nast. Retrieved January 23, 2017. The name of Human Story 3 is a play on the title of the Pixar film Toy Story 3 (2010). Ferraro named the album, given that the company's works were the "mimesis of our reality." He said, "we aggressively celebrate Pixar's cloud-like performance of human emotion, building emotional relationships with CGI characters and accepting them as powerful vehicles of meaningfulness. I personally see them as a marker of the hyper-individualistic age we live in." The instrumental backing often moves into separated moods, repetitive structures and pauses throughout each song, along with abrupt key changes which signify dissonance.Cook-Wilson, Winston (August 17, 2016). "James Ferraro’s Neo-Classical, GPS-Obsessed Americana". Bandcamp Daily. Retrieved January 23, 2017. Musically, Human Story 3 is a modern classical album that returns to the commercial-like, overloaded vaporwave style of Ferraro's Far Side Virtual (2011), only sounding more 'clean' and less focused on pop structures. Most of the digitally made textures and clanging synthesizer sounds on the album blend in with organic instruments such as strings, woodwinds, pianos and professionally recorded real-life choirs. The choral vocals were performed by the Trojans choir of the University of Southern California. Ferraro's biggest reference point for Human Story 3 was 20th century American composer Aaron Copland. Ferraro described Copland as "the purest musical spirit," reasoning that "his music wasn’t just appealing to the common denominator—it’s pandering toward their higher mind. He does that really well: just bringing in all of humanity. It represented something really, really virtuous for me." Ferraro was also influenced by the works of Igor Stravinsky, Erik Satie and Charles Ives in composing Human Story 3. Anna Gaca of Spin magazine compared Human Story 3's feel to that of the Ridley Scott film Blade Runner (1982), where the record's futuristic mood comes from how some of its parts are exaggerated or emotionally amplified. ==Release and promotion== Human Story 3 was announced on May 18, 2016, with a trailer and Ferraro summarizing the album on Twitter as "a musing on hyper individualism and the marketability of neotenous plastics."Bowe, Miles (May 18, 2016). "James Ferraro announces new album Human Story 3". Fact. The Vinyl Factory. Retrieved January 23, 2017. The trailer consist of footage of Financial District, Manhattan.Robinson, Collin (May 18, 2016). "Watch The Trailer For James Ferraro’s Human Story 3". Stereogum. SpinMedia. Retrieved January 23, 2017. The second and third trailers of the album were released on May 24 and May 31 respectively.Mr P (May 24, 2016). "James Ferraro – Human Story 3 (Official Trailer 2)". Tiny Mix Tapes. Retrieved January 23, 2017.Mr P (May 31, 2016). "James Ferraro – Human Story 3 (Official Trailer 3)". Tiny Mix Tapes. Retrieved January 23, 2017. "Ten Songs for Humanity" was the first song released from Human Story 3 on June 7, 2016.Bowe, Miles (June 7, 2016). "James Ferraro sounds angelic on the glossy orchestral left-turn ‘Ten Songs For Humanity’". Fact. The Vinyl Factory. Retrieved January 23, 2017. Ferraro self- released Human Story 3 digitally and on cassette tape on June 14, 2016. The cassette release was a limited edition of only 200 copies. On June 28, 2016, Vice Media's THUMP publication premiered the video for "Plastiglomerate & Co," which they described as a "Web 1.0 rendering of a busy metropolis, gross in its idealized cleanliness; in it, almost faceless, bots bustle about and trample each other in algorithmic harmony."Iadarola, Alexander (June 28, 2016). "James Ferraro Imagines an Automated Human Ant Farm in Chaotic New Video". THUMP. Vice Media. Retrieved January 23, 2017. Miles Bowe of Fact magazine called Human Story 3 "truly American music made by one of this generation’s great composers."Bowe, Miles (July 12, 2016). "The month in Bandcamp: James Ferraro’s new opus, perfect punk and literally just Floral Shoppe backwards". Fact. The Vinyl Factory. Retrieved January 23, 2017. He highlighted that "the album builds on various qualities found in Ferraro’s discography, dragging familiar sounds into exciting, unknown territories." The LP was number 12 on the magazine's year-end list of best Bandcamp releases.Bowe, Miles (December 11, 2016). "The 20 best Bandcamp releases of 2016". Fact. The Vinyl Factory. Retrieved January 23, 2017. The album received a five-out-of-five review from Tiny Mix Tapes,SCVSCV (July 8, 2016). "James Ferraro – Human Story 3". Tiny Mix Tapes. Retrieved January 23, 2017. and landed at number seven on the publication's list of the best albums of 2016, where Jude Noel praised the arrangements as "unabashedly ambitious, towering structures built upon cozy clarinet melodies and unbridled ideology.""2016: Favorite 50 Music Releases". Tiny Mix Tapes. December 14, 2016. Retrieved January 23, 2017. The album's cover art was put at number 13 on the publication's list of best album covers of 2016.Scott Reid, Reed (December 8, 2016). "2016: Favorite Cover Art". Tiny Mix Tapes. Retrieved January 23, 2017. However, in a five-out-of-ten review for Pitchfork, Jayasuriya mainly criticized the album for its lack of subtlety in how it presented its message. He gave descriptions of the record such as it being a "less artful, album- length version" of the song "Fitter Happier" by Radiohead and "just as tiring as" commercial music. ==Track listing== ==Release history== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- !scope="col"|Region !scope="col"|Date !scope="col"|Format(s) !scope="col"|Label |- !scope="row"|Worldwide |June 14, 2016 | |Self-released |} ==References== Category:2016 albums Category:James Ferraro albums Category:Dystopian music
